Award.AwardTitle: Build and Broaden: Growing Capacity in Southeast Alaska Indigenous Genomic Research Partnerships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support a regional approach to building capacity for genomic research partnerships within the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian communities of southeast Alaska. A workshop series will introduce a working group of southeast Alaska Indigenous community representatives to basic genomic research methods through hands-on laboratory exercises. The working group will develop culturally-responsive genomic research policy recommendations and resources that will serve as a potential model for other Indigenous communities, institutions, and their collaborators. In collaboration with Sealaska Heritage Instituteâ€™s STEAM program, insight from the working-group will also be applied to developing a place-based, culturally-responsive genomic laboratory teaching module for Alaska Native middle school students. This pedagogical model will be of interest to other STEM educators serving Indigenous student populations. The workshop activities will strengthen the existing genomic research partnerships between the investigators and further support the training and professionalization of an Alaska Native postdoctoral fellow (PI Bader).

The proposed workshop series will build capacity in southeast Alaska Native communities and the Sealaska Heritage Institute to engage in equitable genomic research partnerships, especially with non-Indigenous collaborators. Workshop activities will produce a genomic research toolkit of resources for Indigenous communities and their collaborators. This toolkit will include a genomic research policy recommendation that will hold genomic researchers accountable to community core cultural values, a cultural competency training module for researchers who wish to engage in genomic research with Indigenous communities in southeast Alaska, and examples of documents like MOU/MOA and informed consent which will highlight key points to be discussed between communities and their research partners. Consortium publications will recommend approaches to critical elements of genomic research (for example, sample management and data sharing) informed by the core values of southeast Alaska Native communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
With biotechnologies being used as tools to address community needs, this project assembled members from Southeast Alaska Indigenous communities into a local working group to discuss genomic research in the region. This genomics working group convened multiple times and worked to create place-based, culturally responsive guidelines for genomic research with Indigenous communities in Southeast Alaska. The guidelines are found in a handbook available to local community members and to broader society to act as a model for communities in other regions of North America and beyond. The project also created two educational videos. The first video provides examples of Indigenous-led projects in Southeast Alaska using science as a tool for community needs. The second video provides an in-depth look at the lab processes for paleogenomics research that communities can use to learn more and ask informed questions when collaborating with scientific researchers on projects.

     This project also trained two Indigenous postdoctoral fellows and one Indigenous graduate student from Southeast Alaska in scientific and community engaged methods. Specifically, one trainee learned about STEAM education and genomic outreach through her collaboration with the Indigenous Science team at Sealaska Heritage Institute, and about science communication through her collaboration with the Sealaska Heritage Institute media team and contractors. She used this training to lead her own media development and communication project using video footage from inside a paleogenomic lab. The other trainees learned how to work together to develop culturally responsive research protocols. 


Last Modified: 12/20/2024
Modified by: Alyssa Bader
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: With biotechnologies being used as tools to address community needs, this project assembled members from Southeast Alaska Indigenous communities into a local working group to discuss genomic research in the region. This genomics working group convened multiple times and worked to create place-based, culturally responsive guidelines for genomic research with Indigenous communities in Southeast Alaska. The guidelines are found in a handbook available to local community members and to broader society to act as a model for communities in other regions of North America and beyond. The project also created two educational videos. The first video provides examples of Indigenous-led projects in Southeast Alaska using science as a tool for community needs. The second video provides an in-depth look at the lab processes for paleogenomics research that communities can use to learn more and ask informed questions when collaborating with scientific researchers on projects. This project also trained two Indigenous postdoctoral fellows and one Indigenous graduate student from Southeast Alaska in scientific and community engaged methods. Specifically, one trainee learned about STEAM education and genomic outreach through her collaboration with the Indigenous Science team at Sealaska Heritage Institute, and about science communication through her collaboration with the Sealaska Heritage Institute media team and contractors. She used this training to lead her own media development and communication project using video footage from inside a paleogenomic lab. The other trainees learned how to work together to develop culturally responsive research protocols. Last Modified: 12/20/2024 Submitted by: AlyssaBader
